title: Applies fair credit reporting act to tenant screening companies
summary: Includes tenant screening companies, associations or agencies within the fair credit reporting act relating to consumer reports of information bearing on a consumer's credit worthiness.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S1896

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the general business law, in relation to applying the fair
credit reporting act to tenant screening companies

PURPOSE:
The purpose of this bill is to prevent tenants from wrongfully being
blacklisted by tenant screening companies

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:
This bill would amend subdivision (e) of section 380-a of the
General Business Law to apply the Fair Credit Reporting Act to tenant
screening companies.

JUSTIFICATION:
Under current New York State Law, tenant screening companies are not
required to abide by the fair credit reporting statutes, which can
lead to the unfair treatment of prospective tenants who may he
unknowingly screened. Screening companies receive fees for their
services from landlords wishing to avoid undesirable tenants.

Problems arise because many tenants are unaware that they are being
screened and are often placed in a position where they cannot refute
dubious information that may be supplied by a not so thorough
screening company. One particular tenant was blacklisted by a Rhode
Island based tenant screening company because the company discovered
that she liked bingo and in their report to the landlord, they listed
her as a "chronic excessive gambler."

This legislation would eliminate such abuse of a tenant's rights by
requiring that the tenant be notified that such an investigation will
be conducted and that the tenant must give written permission for the
report. Upon completion of the report, the tenant is notified and
will receive and inspect a copy of such a report. In addition, the
tenant would receive the same right to
dispute any item of information contained in his/her screening company
to promptly reinvestigate and correct any errors found in such a file.

LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:
03/16/09 REFERRED TO CONSUMER PROTECTION
01/06/10 REFERRED TO CONSUMER PROTECTION

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
None.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act shall take effect on the thirtieth day after it shall become
a law.
